BACKGROUND 1.1 The Agreement on the Gaza Strip and Jericho Area signed in May 1994, and the Agreement on Preparatory Transfer of Powers and Responsibilities, signed in August 1994 gave full responsibility to the Palestinian Authorities (PA) for all public services in Gaza and the Jericho Area, and for selected services, including education and health, in the West Bank. Since August 1994, programs have been developed by the Ministry of Education and Higher Education (MEHE) and the Ministry of Health (MOH) to deliver priority services in the education and health sectors in Gaza and the West Bank and plan for future needs. Both Ministries are demonstrating commitment to the development of leadership and technical skills in their respective sectors. A. WBG Background 1.2 The combined area of the West Bank and Gaza (WBG) is approximately 6,000 square kilometers. The 1993 estimated combined population was about 2.3 million, of which 65 percent resides in the West Bank. More than 50 percent of the combined populations are 15 years old or younger. High birth rates, relatively low mortality rates and changing population migration patterns are contributing to a rapid rise in population in both areas. 1.3 Re ional Differences. The West Bank and Gaza differ in demographics, infrastructure and economic status. Most of the West Bank is highly urbanized, with a rural population dispersed among 422 towns and villages at a population density of 267 persons per square kilometer. The Gaza Strip, with its dense population of 2,225 persons per square kilometer, has only 16 towns and villages. Registered refugees represent 32 percent of the West Bank population, of which slightly more than one-quarter live in refugee camps. In Gaza, 72 percent of the population are registered refugees, of which about 55 percent live in camps. GNP per capita is significantly lower in Gaza. Gaza was previously administered by Egypt, while the West Bank was unified with Jordan. This resulted in differences in service provision, such as the use of different school curricula. B. Sectoral Background and Issues The Education Sector 1.4 Background. MEHE has proved motivated and efficient in its initial operations. Although it inherited the school system only three days before the schools were scheduled to open for the 1994- 95 academic year, it opened them on time; rapidly arranged for textbooks publication and distribution;, filled top positions with competent individuals; fulfilled complex arrangements for paying their salaries; and located suitable office premises. Immediate priorities for the MEHE are to continue operations and repair and maintain the system's physical and human capital. MEHE also has to begin to redesign the system so that it becomes financially sustainable, supports the development of a Palestinian identity among WBG children and youth, and promotes the high standards of knowledge and skill required for the economic development of WBG. 1.5 Size and Structure. Education in WBG is divided into preschool (ages 3-5); primary (ages 6-11); preparatory (ages 12-14); secondary (ages 15-17); and post-secondary (ages 18 +). Only primary and preparatory schooling are compulsory. There are no separate preparatory schools; primary schools covering either grades 1-6 or 1-9 and secondary schools cover grades 7-12 or 10-12. The secondary level includes academic and vocational education, the latter sometimes being offered in separate schools and sometimes incorporated into academic schools. Annex 1 shows the structure of

Annex 2 shows school statistics. 1.6 In 1993 there were reported to be a total of 1,282 primary and secondary schools in WBG, accommodating close to 590,000 students in grades 1-12. About 80 percent of these schools (1,044) are located in the West Bank, and the rest are in the Gaza Strip. Around 25 percent (321 schools) offer secondary education; most of these secondary schools also provide accommodation for basic students. 1.7 Management and Financing. Operating responsibilities for WBG schools fall under (i) the PA (73 percent of all schools); (ii) UNRWA (14 percent); and (iii) the private sector (13 percent). Current operating responsibilities are based on a combination of pre- and post-autonomy structures. The new education authority (MEHE) has two regional divisions; one for Gaza and one for the West Bank. Within the regional divisions, there are district offices which essentially ran the schools under the Israeli Civil Administration--they admitted students, appointed/transferred teachers, trained teachers, built and maintained schools, collected data for management purposes, provided textbooks and school furniture, supervised the educational process, supervised and licensed private schools. Allocation of responsibility between administrative levels has not yet been fully developed by the MEHE. District offices collect student fees ($20.00 for basic education and $27.00 for senior secondary students) and apportion them among the schools, MEHE, and the district itself. Additional revenues are generated from the proceeds of school canteens, community contributions to school building and maintenance, and through municipal taxes. The MOH has made substantial progress in initial steps towards cost recovery, including a health insurance scheme and the collection of local taxes. Both sectors are actively seeking ways to become financially viable. 1.8 Education Sector Issues. The sector faces five inunediate issues, with long-term implications: (a) rapidly increasing enrollments; (b) inadequate and poorly maintained facilities; (c) shortage of teaching materials and inadequately trained teachers; (d) unmet needs of disadvantaged groups; and (e) lack of experience in sector policy and management. (a) Enrollments. Given the very young demographic profile of the WBG population, each year an estimated 18,000 new student places' need to be created. The existing facilities cannot accommodate these large numbers and budgetary constraints severely limit the number of new schools that can be constructed. To keep expenditures at a manageable level, the Ministry would in the near future need to consider policy changes that would optimize the use of its school facilities. At present the majority of schools in Gaza operate on a double shift system, whereas most of the West Bank schools operate on single shift basis. (b) Inadeguate Facilities and Maintenance. UNRWA and the Israeli Civil Administration rationalized school locations relative to their jurisdictions, but not relative to WBG as a single service area. As a result, locations of schools do not always match the residential catchment area of school children, causing some students to walk as far as six kilometers each way to attend classes. Many schools built in the 1950s-1960s were poorly designed and constructed. About 1,400 classrooms (17 percent) of 8,200 classrooms in West Bank are using rented houses, resulting in uneconomically small classes, wasting teacher resources. Finally, many schools are dilapidated because of lack of preventive maintenance. (c) Shortage of Teaching Materials and Inadequate Teacher Training. The West Bank is using a revised Jordanian curriculum while Gaza is at present using an Egyptian curriculum. Around 30 percent of teachers are teaching in fields for which they are not trained. In particular, some 37 percent of those teaching science have no formal or major training in this field. Results of the 1991 International Assessment of Education Progress (IAEP II) student assessment pointed to overall poor pedagogical skills in science and mathematics teaching. Schools also lack supplementary reading materials, libraries, science equipment and laboratories and basic equipment such as globes, maps and other teaching aids. Annex 3 describes supplementary reading needs. (d) Unmet Needs for Disadvantaged Groups. There are several educationally disadvantaged groups with differing needs: (a) high school students who could not sit for their baccalaureate exam because of the Intifada; (b) students still in the school system whose education was interrupted during the Intifada, facing educational and emotional difficulties2; and (c) the developmentally disabled. There are few trained staff and no programs designed to meet the needs of these groups. (e) Sector Policy and Management. Reliable data on which to base policy decisions are lacking, and few staff have experience in education system management. In the long-term, the Ministry would need to prepare for merger with the UNRWA system, and address related issues, including the variation between MEHE and UNRWA teacher salaries. The Health Sector 1.9 Background. In 1991 while still under the Israeli Civil Administration, health expenditures for Gaza and the West Bank represented approximately $US200 million3. Compared to other countries in the region, health care expenditures in WBG were relatively high per capita. Life expectancy was 65 years; infant mortality rate was estimated at 40-60 per 1,000 births. Health care facility and personnel ratios were barely adequate: 1. 1 physicians, 0.9 nurses and midwives, and 1. 1 beds per 1,000 population. Resources were unevenly distributed and quality varied greatly. Gaza and the most remote areas of the West Bank were and continue to be disadvantaged in terms of health facilities and personnel. 1.10 Size and Structure. UNRWA (restricted to registered refugees), NGOs, and the private sector also provide health care services. These agencies provide primary care as well as hospital care, directly through their own facilities or through contracts. The public sector operates 205 primary health care facilities, UNRWA operates 41, and NGOs, 192. The West Bank has 15 hospitals of which 9 are public, 6 are run by NGOs, and I by UNRWA. There are five hospitals in Gaza, 4 public and one NGO. A new UNRWA hospital is under construction in Gaza. There is also a sizeable private health care sector. There are two public sector psychiatric hospitals, one in the West Bank and one in Gaza which provide some community based outpatient services. Mental health services are also provided by a range of NGOs. 2/ An internal UNRWA assessment of Gazan schools for 1989/90 found significant losses of school time during the Intifada. The surprisingly poor performance of West Bank eighth graders on the 1993 IAEP, even relative to Jordanian children who had the same curriculum, seems at least partly attributable to the cumulative effects of lost educational time. 3/ This represented about 7 percent of Gross National Product, or about 9 percent of Gross Domestic Product, a per capita expenditure of about $USI 10.0 per year. This is high for countries of comparable income.
 1.11 Management and Financing. Following the assumption of complete responsibility for all public sector health services in WBG, MOH has rapidly begun to operationalize essential policies outlined in the Palestinian Health Plan. MOH maintains its primary office in Gaza City while the Deputy Minister's office is located in Nablus in the West Bank. Annex 4 shows the organizational structure of the MOH. The existing PA health insurance scheme is compulsory for PA employees and voluntary for others. Employees pay 5% of basic salary up to a maximum of NIS 73.00 per month. In 1994, about 45 % of the population in Gaza was insured and it is expected that estimated health insurance revenue will cover 41 % of the anticipated public sector health expenditures for Gaza in 1995.4 Efforts are being made to extend coverage. Registered refugees have access to UNRWA clinics and hospitals and also have access to public sector facilities if living outside refugee camps. There is a growing private sector providing a wide range of services including maternity and specialist diagnostic services. About US$25.0 million was spent in 1991 on health through private- for-profit or private MDs, and clinics. There are two main private insurance companies providing health insurance to about 10,000 households. 1.12 Health Sector Issues. There are five principal issues: (a) inadequate infrastructure; (b) variability in quality of and access to services; (c) weak sector management; (d) unmet needs of special populations and (e) lack of sector policy development. (a) Inadeguate Infrastructure. The 14 hospitals and 205 primary health care clinics administered by the MOH in the WB and Gaza have suffered from two decades of serious under investment. Facilities have become increasingly inadequate to serve the rising population dependent on them - particularly in Gaza. Physical facilities, which in many cases date from the British mandate and, in some, from the years of Turkish administrators, have deteriorated from neglect of necessary maintenance. In many - if not most - locations: electrical installations are outdated, unreliable and sometimes hazardous (providing for poor lighting, inoperable elevators etc); sanitary facilities are substandard; and heating is inadequate or non-existent. (b) Variation in Quality and Availability of Health Care Services. The quality of health care, measured by staffing, service volume ratios, as well as the condition of facilities varies substantially by geographic location and sponsor. In the West Bank, each primary clinic serves approximately 3,000 persons, contrasted with the average clinic in Gaza that serves 11,000; on a comparative basis, an UNRWA clinic might perform two to eleven times the volume of visits as a similarly staffed NGO clinic. In addition, there is no standardization of services; supervision and management quality vary significantly, and MOH services suffer from limited training opportunities for staff. There are shortages of para- professionals and nurses. (c) Sector Management. There are few experienced health system administrators and little accurate data. Management is made more difficult by the different priorities of the West Bank and Gaza. Gaza needs to increase services to meet the needs of an extremely dense population, while the West Bank needs to rationalize and improve existing services. The geographical separation of MOH in Gaza City and the Deputy Minister's office in Nablus (West Bank) complicates matters further as regular contact between the two areas is difficult due to obstacles in border crossing and unpredictable telephone services. In addition, MOH is eventually to assume the added responsibility of providing health services to the refugee population (1.1 million) that is currently served by UNRWA. In preparation, steps are being taken to foster compatibility between the two systems. 4/ Annual Report, 1990-94. Palestinian Health Authority, Ministry of Health. April, 1995.

A cross-cutting issue for the health sector is the further development and provision of community mental health services to identify and treat those of all ages who have been adversely affected by the recent upheavals, as well as provide appropriate long-term services to the general population. (e) Sector Policy. Investments strategies should be more consistent with health needs and expected outcomes. Causes for low sectoral efficiency include: (i) proliferation of very small hospitals (70 percent of hospitals have under 100 beds); (ii) provision of highly specialized medical procedures in uneconomical units; (iii) insufficient attention to preventive activities particularly for women and children. Therefore, not enough attention has been given to the balance between individual care and public health programs, and to improving the efficiency of hospital care, the most expensive part of the health system. The development of effective health investment and financing strategies are priorities for the sector. C. Development Strategies 1.13 Ministrv of Education Development Strategv. MEHE strategy has emphasized the immediate needs of the school system including: curriculum unification; improvement of school infrastructure; provision of special support to disadvantaged groups; provision of improved learning materials and textbooks; and improvement of education administration. Longer-term policy development is being undertaken through initial sector work and technical assistance provided through cooperative efforts by the Bank, UNESCO and other donors. 1.14 Establishing a financing framework for the system is a high priority. Currently the PA is highly dependent on donors for recurrent budget support for 1995, a financing gap of US$228 million has been identified and donors will attempt to finance this deficit. As elsewhere, education expenditures, particularly wages, consume a large proportion of central budgets. The education sector lacks senior administrative staff with experience in sector analysis, policy making, and resource allocation. Reliable baseline data for allocation decisions are often not available. MEHE plans to put an Education Management Information System (EMIS) in place to collect data and monitor and evaluate programs. It also plans to improve its budgeting, planning, financial analysis, and policy development capacities. 1.15 Ministry of Health Development Strategy. The Palestinian Health Plan sets out five objectives: (a) improve health sector management; (b) develop primary health care including disease prevention, health promotion and health protection, as well improve basic secondary care; (c) improve the professional skills of health personnel; (d) emphasize quality of care at all levels; and (e) focus attention on the special needs of women, children, the poor, and groups disadvantaged by the political disturbances. As part of the strategy to improve the quality of services, MOH plans to support the development and use of communication systems, including information collection and transfer, and human interaction capabilities, such as tele-conferencing. 1.16 Health has taken as its policy centerpiece a commitment to accessible, high quality primary health care for the Palestinian people, delivered principally through a network of Comprehensive Health Centers (CHC)5. The strategic location and service capabilities of these centers would allow them to receive referrals from local health centers, clinics and health posts, and make appropriate 5/ CHCs are a more cost-effective hub for preventive, primary rapid-response services, including normal deliveries and emergencies not requiring hospitalization, in contrast to hospital-based outpatient services. Rapid response services would be staffed by a physician-led team and would be available 24 hours, seven days a week. All other services for children and adults, including preventive, curative, rehabilitative and chronic care, would be available, for patient convenience, during day-time as well as evening hours.

The CHCs function as regional centers for staff development and for public health monitoring and program implementation. 1.17 CHCs can potentially reduce total system expenditures directly, by delivering medical care with substantially lower unit costs (currently US$4-6 per visit). In contrast, the average expenditure per patient day for all hospital patients in 1992, was US$94. 17. If well implemented, the MOH design would successfully constrain capital investments for the expansion of acute hospital beds. It is envisaged that upgraded CHCs would lessen the need for uneconomical hospital investments. Future hospital capital investments and development of services would be based on cost effectiveness criteria. 1.18 Bank Group Strategy and Rationale for Bank Involvement. Present Bank policy for the WBG has four main themes which were identified in close collaboration with the Palestinian counterpart team in December, 1993 and form the foundation of the "Emergency Assistance Program for the Occupied Territories": (a) restoring and further developing basic and social infrastructures; (b) building policy-making and institutional capabilities; (c) supporting the emergence of the private sector; and (d) sustaining the financial viability of the PA. The Bank has been in the forefront of institutional efforts to help the PA define a feasible rehabilitation and development strategy. It has played a prominent role in setting a policy and investment framework with the six-volume study "Developing the Occupied Territories: An Investment in Peace;" the establishment of the Trust Fund for Gaza (TFG) in 1993; and its administrator role in the operation of the Technical Assistance Trust Fund and the Holst Fund (the latter for recurrent cost financing). As the Secretariat for the Ad Hoc Liaison Committee, the Bank supplies regular information and analysis on aid flows and requirements to all parties. To participate in the financing of the reconstruction effort, the Bank has set up the TFG (US$50 million) from its own surplus of which US$30.0 million was allocated to the Emergency Rehabilitation Project (ERP) and the balance of US$20.0 million is being allocated to this project. 1.19 The Bank has been providing the technical underpinning and framework for the effective use of emergency relief funds since September 1993. The proposed project supports the objectives of the Bank's strategy (para. 1.18). The project would also build on the ERP which focused on rehabilitation and improvement of existing school plant and equipment, provision of textbooks, and some capacity building. The available level of financing ($20.5 million), was inadequate to address urgent education sector needs. Furthermore, ERP did not address the needs of the health sector. Bank involvement in the appraisal of the WBG Education and Health Rehabilitation Program, and in the financing of this project would be expected to mobilize donor financing for the unfunded portions of the Program described below. The longer-term objective is to assist both MEHE and MOH develop sustainable sector strategies and establish themselves as effective institutions. To reach these objectives, support is needed in three areas: (a) rehabilitation and essential expansion of selected education and health facilities; (b) improvement in service provision; and (c) capacity building and institutional development of the education and health ministries. Program investments and activities have been estimated for a 3-year period.

The ERP includes an education component which addressed some needs (rehabilitation of schools and provision of textbooks). Due to political and institutional issues, implementation of the WBG donor assistance program has incurred delays. The project aims to support and maintain existing services, while assisting the PA in developing longer-term strategies for economic sustainability. Technical assistance would help both MEHE and MOH review and rationalize their finances in the immediate future. Education in the WBG is not free. Fees of US$20.00 and US$27.00 are paid by students in Grades 1-10 and 11-12 respectively. Although there are some exemptions, revenue from fees is estimated at about US$8.0 million. The immediate recurrent costs generated by project-financed inputs would be modest. In the case of education, new classrooms and schools built (40-student capacity) would help reduce teacher requirements. Many existing schools currently operating in rented facilities (old houses) where the classrooms are small, are wasting teacher resources. Palestinian society places very high value on education and the communities have over the years, particularly during the intifada, built and maintained many schools. Funds are frequently raised by the communities to upgrade schools. These initiatives would be maximized by the PA through a "matching fund" program that would build schools in communities that provide contributions (in cash, in kind and land) ranging from 20% to 80% of the investment. Communities have already donated land for the construction of new schools representing a value of about US$3.6 million in West Bank. In the

Overall, the project is expected to improve the efficiency and equity of educational and health services for a population of about one million people in Gaza. The project is also expected to increase the efficiency of health and education expenditures through more rational resource allocations and better cost recovery mechanisms. In addition, the project would serve as a catalyst to attract cofinancing for implementation of the comprehensive Program. Finally, project activities would contribute to stabilizing the social environment and creating a positive atmosphere for future growth in the region.

 Annex 5 Page 1 of 3 WEST BANK AND GAZA EDUCATION AND HEALTH REHABILITATION PROJECT Special Studies: Managed Care. Cost Containment and Financial Sustainability 1. Objective. The project aims to support the analysis, identification and adoption of short-term measures that contribute to the fiscal solvency of the MOH. Among the most critical cost issues faced by the MOH are: (a) the high cost of treatments abroad, including services from Israeli hospitals, (b) cost of pharmaceuticals as a proportion of total health expenditures, and (b) unexplored revenue generating targets. 2. Rationale. As a complement to the Technical Assistance Trust Fund, the EHRP special studies are intended to address more immediate solutions to pressing issues of sustainability. A select set of high cost budget line items are the focus of these studies. An objective review of current operating activities, in light of potential managed care application, would guide the rapid adoption of cost containment measure. Application in the management, as well as patient service arenas is anticipated. 3. Components. This component would consist of two special studies. One would address managed care practices and their potential application and adoption. The other would address data identification and collection to monitor financial sustainability and monitoring triggers for fiscal corrective actions. 4. Implementing Agency. In collaboration with the Finance Unit of the MOH, the special studies would be conducted by local or foreign consultants with expertise int he subject matter. 5. Cost Estimates. Each study would cost approximately US$80,000 and would be conducted during a 6 month timeframe. 6. Risks. The possibility that the TAFT project addresses and solves either of these issues during its early work would preclude the necessity of these studies. 7. Sustainability. As special studies to be conducted in the specified time frame, this component would not generate recurrent costs for the MOH.
 Annex 5 Page 2 of 3 Quality Improvement of Health Services 1. Objective. The project aims to improve the efficiency and quality of health services provided in all public sector facilities by responding to consumer preferences and demands. 2. Rationale. New physical health system infrastructure, specifically in the form of district-base Comprehensive Health Centers, is substantially more relevant when created as part of a larger program for system reform, including a new emphasis on quality and efficiency of resource use. Not only the new facilities, but all public sector facilities, should incorporate activities of problem identification, team problem solving and solution implementation in order to advance the operational functioning and management of health services. 3. Components. The quality improvement project would be initiated with hospital and PHC teams though a combination of: (a) training workshops aimed at improving the work environment of Palestinian health facilities; (b) applied exercises in a variety of field settings and documentation of results; (c) methods developed for measuring and evaluating comparative improvement exercises; and (d) dissemination of improvement strategies to enhance professional communication and stimulate experimentation with corrective measures. Two important subjects are targeted initially: services--general level of cleanliness, patient reception, admission procedures, visiting habits, patient satisfaction, waiting times, staff overwork/underwork, renovation and maintenance problems, overcrowding, poor compliance with schedules; and information--medical records, appointment systems, sign posing, defining services provided, regulation and procedures, job description/responsibility/authority, channels of communication and patient follow-up. 4. Implementing Agency. The initial workshops would be conducted as a joint project between the Ministry of Health, the Planning and Research Center, the Quality of Health Care Unit of the Palestine Council of Health and the Al-Najah University. The Quality of Health Care Unit would be responsible for the development of the Quality Improvement project throughout the Palestinian health system. 5. Cost Estimates. Base cost estimates were based on: (a) thirty man-months of international specialist services at US$450,000; (b) sixty man-months of local specialist services at US$120,000; (c) training costs at US$500,000; (d) materials and supplies at US$179,000; and (e) equipment at US$37,000.
 Annex 5 Page 3 of 3 Comrnunication Links for Health System Development 1. Objective. The project focus is the development of staff and management structures by improving information transfer, easing communication within and between the medical communities of Gaza and the West Bank, and using communication technology to provide more widespread access to training for all levels and types of PHC and hospital staff with maximum flexibility for use throughout operating hours. 2. Rationale. Information transfer, and thus communication between Gaza and the West Bank, is conducted infrequently, constrained as it is by undeveloped communication infrastructure and travel restrictions. Communication technologies are increasingly serving as the bridge between distant communities, for example the use of telemedicine for medical diagnostic conferencing and referral, and accounting and record keeping. Benefits from the use of communication technologies include: cost recovery potential, re-usable in-service training and new-staff orientation modules, reduced costs and time of travel for physicians and patients, an integrated referral system linking all levels of care, selective cost-effective contracting with specialist physicians, standardizing and unifying medical practice patterns and a unified records system, for accounting and medical information. 3. Components. The project would support a feasibility study to document and cost the potential applications and feasibility of establishing multiple communication links within and between Gaza and the West Bank. A pilot project to be funded by donors would establish demonstration sites to test the cost-effectiveness of communication link centers, between Comprehensive Health Centers, select referral hospitals and relevant public sector offices, for example the MOH Finance Unit. 4. Implementing Agencv. In part, the project would extend activities already underway in the MOH's Health Management Information System Unit with initial donor support and collaboration. 5. Cost Estimates. The initial study, estimated at about US$80,000 and to be conducted in a six-month period, would be funded by the TFG. Infrastructure development costs (including local communication loop, and building site requirements) are the most complex to design and estimate. Preliminary base costs for a pilot project are estimated at US$827,000 including, equipment, training and operational costs are expected to be funded by a donor. 6. Risks. Given the phased nature of the program components, potential risks are minimized. However, there are two potential problems envisaged: (a) the MOH's ability to assume recurrent costs related with such a system, particularly its servicing requirements; and (b) practical limitations of telephone lines and other requirements for communications which are not in place at present. The latter would be mitigated by improvements in the telecommunications systems, a process that has started already. 7. Sustainability. The availability of private sector services, already being piloted, may reduce the associated capital and operating costs to the MOH, and the services provided would positively impact the efficient operation of public sector health services. Of the approximately 1,031 schools in the WBG administered by the MEHE (888 in the 8 districts of the WB and 143 in Gaza), 669 (65%) have been identified for upgrading and are represented in the request for financing their rehabilitation, and expansion of educational facilities (628 on the WB and 41 in Gaza). Of these, some 72% are basic schools 18% are secondary schools and 10% are combined basic and secondary schools. 2. None of the schools for which financial assistance is sought are among the substantial number of MEHE administered schools being housed in rented premises with all the disadvantages of such acconmmodation constructed for other than educational purposes (e.g. rooms often too small for 40 student classes). Most of the "owned" schools for which rehabilitation or expansion is required have been planned and constructed for use as schools, but such planning has been undertaken over many years, under different circumstances, different administrative authorities and even by local communities on a "self help" basis, and are far from uniform. 3. Physical facilities for many of these schools have deteriorated as a result of years of neglect and inadequate funding for routine maintenance. By the time they were inherited by the MEHE in mid 1994, they were generally in poor, and in places dangerous, condition. The paucity of financial support over the last two decades has also prevented necessary expansion of the facilities and led to current overcrowding at many schools (which would only become worse with continuing enrollment increases), and to inadequate provisions of sanitary facilities and specialized teaching premises. 4. Since the establishment of the MEHE, the Director General of Buildings and Projects (DGBP) has been developing appropriate space norms and building standards for the necessary expansions and replacements of existing facilities. 5. The Ministry's program for maintaining, upgrading and developing its education facilities, in the order of its perceived priority of needs is: (a) increasing the capacity of physical facilities to accommodate projected enrollment increases either (i) by expansion of existing facilities or, where existing sites and structures do not permit, adequate horizontal or vertical expansion, (ii) by construction of new schools; (b) replacing existing facilities where they are either (i) dangerous or (ii) too dilapidated for rehabilitation to be economically feasible; (c) alleviating current overcrowding by extension of existing facilities or by vertical or horizontal completion of partially constructed community financed schools;
 Annex 14 Page 2 of 2 (d) extending existing facilities to incorporate such specialized premises as laboratories, where required to meet curricular needs, and such essential ancillary facilities as toilet blocks, where not available; and (e) preserving existing facilities by rectifying the legacy of neglected maintenance through rehabilitation and repair of defects. However, in the implementation process, some or all of these activities would often be accomplished simultaneously under unified contracts, as many schools feature several or all of the deficiencies and needs noted. 6. Consultant architects, selected from the merged PECDAR/UNRWA/UNDP lists of approved firms, would be engaged in accordance with IDA guidelines for the design of new buildings at project schools and for the supervision of their construction. The consultants would be issued by the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) with "architects briefs" incorporating schedules of required accommodation, construction areas and cost limitations for works at the schools concerned. For schools requiring only minor construction works (e.g. toilet blocks), minor non-structural completion of existing structures or comprehensive maintenance, the construction documents, (specifications and drawings) would be prepared by the Construction Section of the PCU and site engineers would be hired on a temporary basis to supervise construction. For schools requiring only comprehensive maintenance work, the construction documents would be prepared either by (a) the PCU staff or (b) the site engineer hired for construction supervision at the schools concerned. 7. Procurement of construction works (as also procurement of equipment, furniture and textbook needs) would be carried out in accordance with procedures described under Annex 13. 8. Construction operations would be supervised at several levels. The Construction Section of the PCU would provide overall control and supervision of all construction operations. The engineer at each District Education Office would assist in supervising construction works at schools in his district, by means of periodic visits and the submission of monthly reports to the PCU. Where the remote locations of a number of construction sites may deter visits by the district engineer, a supervision manager may be hired on a temporary basis for the periodic supervision of the group of sites and the provision of interim reports to the district engineer. Continuous on-site supervision would be provided at each construction site by a site engineer hired on a temporary basis. EDFACIL.ANX

The 14 hospitals and 205 primary health care centers administered by the MOH in the West bank and Gaza have generally been developed in an apparently piecemeal, unsystematic manner, without any discernable indication of any standard approach or adherence to any long-range planning objectives: Hospital infrastructure complexes have, in the main, evolved over many years: the earliest component buildings dating in some cases from the years of Turkish administration; others from the British mandate period and some from post second world war years, the 1940s/50s. Premises for the more recently initiated primary health care programs are largely ad hoc provisions, many of them makeshift conversions of, often rented, buildings constructed for other uses from sometimes as long ago as Turkish times. 2. These physical facilities have suffered from two decades of serious under investment. With only minor extensions for capacity increase having been financed, the institutions have become increasingly inadequate to serve the burgeoning populations dependant on them. They have also deteriorated as a result of years of neglect through inadequate funding for routine maintenance: electrical installations are outdated, unreliable and , in some cases, hazardous (lighting being poor, elevators sometimes inoperable, etc), sanitary facilities sub-standard and provisions for heating premises inadequate or non- existent. 3. Construction proposals for upgrading and expanding West Bank hospitals, which were partially prepared by Israeli architects during the 1980s, have been handed over to the MOH by the Israeli civil authorities. They are to be reviewed by qualified consultants and, if necessary, modified during completion as appropriate for changing Palestinian needs and limited resources. A technical consultant to the Minister and MOH staff engineers have developed a prototype implementation schedule, space norms and building standards for the primary health care centers which are the top priority of the Ministry's program. 4. The Ministry's program for rehabilitating, upgrading and expanding its health facilities, in the order of its perceived priority of needs is: (a) rehabilitating and expanding existing comprehensive, district-based, primary health care centers; (b) replacing existing comprehensive, district-based, comprehensive health care centers and existing local community primary health care centers (health posts) which are too dilapidated for rehabilitation to be economically feasible; (c) rehabilitating and furnishing selected hospitals in Gaza;

The activities to be supported under the proposed project, including rehabilitation and construction of schools, primary health care centers and hospitals, have been placed in environmental screening category "B" due to their limited scope and the restricted nature of their potential impacts. 2. Debris generated from the construction activities, as well as medical and solid wastes from rehabilitated clinics and hospitals, would be properly disposed, and waste management procedures would be introduced to mitigate any negative environmental impact of the proposed project. Any new facilities would require the environmental review by the Bank, Palestinian environmental authorities and Palestinian archeological authorities. Mitigation and monitoring measures, outlined in Table 1, are proposed during the implementation and operation of the investment activities. Existing Situation Institutions 3. The leading Palestinian institution involved in the preparation of environmental protection policies and regulations is the Environmental Planning Directorate of the Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation (MOPIC). The Ministry of Health (MOH) and the Palestine Council of Health are responsible for the environmental health issues, including hospital waste handling procedures. 4. At the municipal level public health and environment departrnents are involved in the environmnent related activities. Delivery of solid waste, as well as sanitation services, are the responsibility of municipalities. Legal and Regulatory Framework 5. Environmental legislation is still under development in the West Bank and Gaza. Currently there are no specific environmental standards regulating solid and medical waste disposal. However, the MOPIC with the support of the German Technical Cooperation (GTZ) is being prepared specific guidelines for solid and hazardous waste management, including medical waste. 6. With regard to rehabilitation and construction of new educational facilities, under ongoing Emergency Rehabilitation Project (ERP), environmental guidelines are being prepared for educational support actions. Waste Disposal 7. In the absence of explicit environmental standards and procedures, the undisinfected medical wastes in the West Bank and Gaza are presently collected and co-disposed with household wastes at
 Annex 16 Page 2 of 4 uncontrolled dumping sites, creating conditions that may lead to the proliferation of diseases and groundwater contamination. 8. Some of medical wastes are burnt on site, contributing to air and soil pollution. Incompletely incinerated wastes could also present health hazards. 9. Construction debris are simply dumped on vacant lots and coastline, destroying natural landscapes, and living and green areas. 10. Wastewater from hospitals are discharged into municipal sewers or directly into the sea with no prior treatment. Some of municipalities have wastewater collection sewage systems and the few wastewater treatment plants that have been constructed have generally failed to operate as designed. Recent Environmental Activities 11. Two controlled landfills are being developed in the Gaza Strip with funding from the European Union and Germany, and the completion of works is scheduled for the end of 1995. The Gaza sanitary landfill will contain special cells for the disposal of medical and hazardous wastes. 12. The Spanish Governrment recently donated three medical waste incinerators which will be installed soon at Shifta and Al-Nasr hospitals in Gaza, and at Nasser hospital in Khan Younes. 13. Several sewerage and drainage works, and wastewater treatment studies are under way in the context of the Bank's ERP and other bilateral, and multilateral activities. Project Related Environmental Issues and Actions Construction Works 14. During construction period, several operations could result in locally significant air pollution from dust, water pollution from improper disposal of lubricants from heavy equipment, and localized flooding during storms due to the transport of poorly controlled sediment from excavation sites into drainage system. 15. Temporary inconvenience due to construction works would be minimized through planning and coordination with local authorities and contractors. In densely populated areas, noisy or vibration generating activities would be strictly confided in the day-time. Construction sites would be fenced off in order to prevent entry of public, and general construction safety measures would be imposed. 16. Construction debris would be disposed at selected sites and eventually recycled. Used concrete blocks could be crushed and used as gravel substitute in the road and construction projects. 17. Environmental monitoring would be carried out by local authorities in order to ensure that measures are enforced to minimize construction impacts.

Inadequate handling and disposal of medical wastes from rehabilitated health centers and hospitals may lead to the transmission of HIV, hepatitis, meningitis and other infectious diseases through injuries caused by syringe needles contaminated by human blood. The group most at risk are medical care workers, waste management operators and scavengers. 19. In order to coordinate ongoing activities related to medical waste, and review and recommend the optimal collection and disposal arrangement, a comprehensive medical waste management study would be carried out under the Technical Assistance Trust Fund financing. This study would contain a survey of medical wastes in the West Bank and Gaza, develop guidelines, awareness and training programs, investigate technical alternatives, assess environmental impacts and determine management options, including private sector participation in medical waste management. 20. Due to an emergency character of the project, the study would, in the first place, develop the pragmatic, short-term solutions, and then address the medium and long-term strategic plan for the medical waste management. Environmental Education and Public Awareness 21. The management of medical waste requires diligence and care from a chain people, starting with medical car staff, continuing through collection workers, and finishing with disposal operators. If any of these are lacking of knowledge and careless in their work, or allow scavengers or children access to the waste, the chain is broken and dangers of infection follow. 22. The project would provide training courses for all of hospitals and clinics' staff to make them aware of hazards from medical waste, especially from infected sharps, and to educate patients and visitors in hospital hygiene and cleanliness with reference to waste. 23. Training of personnel would not be solely to explain routine procedures, but would also cover emergency procedures, such as what action should be taken as a result of a spillage of particular types of waste, or an injury involving a needle. 24. The segregation of waste would be introduced in all of rehabilitated hospitals and clinics, and monitoring procedures would be developed. 25. Public awareness campaigns would be held at the community level in the West Bank and Gaza. Both children and adults would be aware of the risks posed by medical waste, so that they keep away from risks themselves and warn the authorities if they see unacceptable practices. 26. Environment sensitization courses would be introduced into school's curriculum and textbooks. doc.abstracts: The Education and Health Rehabilitation Project will concentrate on upgrading the neglected physical infrastructure in both sectors, and addressing quality of service and institutional development issues in health. Institutional development and some quality aspects in the education sector will be funded by donors. The Project will consist of the following two components: (i) the education sector; and (ii) the health sector.
